title: Francis Joseph Magner
text:
Francis Joseph Magner (March 18, 1887 – June 13, 1947) was an <a href="Americans">American</a> <a href="prelate">prelate</a> of the <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic Church</a>. He served as <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Marquette">Bishop of Marquette</a> from 1941 to 1947.
Early life and education.
Francis Magner was born in <a href="Wilmington%2C%20Will%20County%2C%20Illinois">Wilmington</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, to James and Margaret (née Follen) Magner. He was the third of eight children; one sister, Elizabeth, joined the <a href="Sisters%20of%20Mercy">Sisters of Mercy</a> and one brother, James, also became a <a href="Priesthood%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">priest</a> and served as a <a href="professor">professor</a> at the <a href="The%20Catholic%20University%20of%20America">Catholic University of America</a>. His father, who worked as a <a href="farmer">farmer</a> and later became a <a href="merchant">merchant</a>, also served as a city commissioner and <a href="alderman">alderman</a>.
After graduating from <a href="St.%20Ignatius%20College%20Prep">St. Ignatius College</a> in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, Magner attended <a href="St.%20Mary%27s%20College%20%28Kansas%29">St. Mary's College</a> in <a href="Kansas">Kansas</a>. He continued his studies in <a href="Rome">Rome</a> at the <a href="Pontifical%20North%20American%20College">Pontifical North American College</a>. He earned a <a href="Doctor%20of%20Philosophy">Doctor of Philosophy</a> degree from the <a href="Pontifical%20Urbaniana%20University">University of Propaganda</a> in 1909, and a bachelor's degree in <a href="Canon%20law%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">canon law</a> from <a href="Pontifical%20Roman%20Athenaeum%20S.%20Apollinare">Apollinarus University</a> in 1911.
Priesthood.
While in Rome, Magner was <a href="Holy%20Orders">ordained</a> to the priesthood for the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Chicago">Archdiocese of Chicago</a> on May 17, 1913. His first assignment, following his return to Illinois, was as a <a href="curate">curate</a> at <a href="http%3A//www.stmarynativity.com/">St. Mary Nativity Church</a> in <a href="Joliet%2C%20Illinois">Joliet</a>. He later served in the same capacity at <a href="http%3A//stpiusvparish.org/">St. Pius V Church</a> and <a href="http%3A//smhg60.com/St%2520Mel%2520Holy%2520Ghost%2520History807.htm">St. Mel Church</a>, both in Chicago, and at <a href="http%3A//www.sfxparish.org/">St. Francis Xavier Church</a> in <a href="Wilmette%2C%20Illinois">Wilmette</a>. He then served as <a href="pastor">pastor</a> of <a href="http%3A//www.stjamesschoolhwd.org/parish/index.aspx">St. James Church</a> in <a href="Highwood%2C%20Illinois">Highwood</a> (1924–27) and of <a href="http%3A//www.stmaryevanston.org/">St. Mary Church</a> in <a href="Evanston%2C%20Illinois">Evanston</a> (1927–41). He was named a <a href="monsignor">monsignor</a> in 1939.
Episcopacy.
On December 21, 1940, Magner was appointed the seventh <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Marquette">Bishop of Marquette</a>, <a href="Michigan">Michigan</a>, by <a href="Pope%20Pius%20XII">Pope Pius XII</a>. He received his <a href="Bishop%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">episcopal</a> <a href="consecration">consecration</a> on February 24, 1941, from Archbishop <a href="Samuel%20Stritch">Samuel Stritch</a>, with Bishops <a href="Eugene%20J.%20McGuinness">Eugene J. McGuinness</a> and <a href="William%20David%20O%27Brien">William O'Brien</a> serving as <a href="Consecrator">co-consecrators</a>, at <a href="Holy%20Name%20Cathedral%2C%20Chicago">Holy Name Cathedral</a> in Chicago. His installation took place at <a href="St.%20Peter%20Cathedral%2C%20Marquette">St. Peter Cathedral</a> in <a href="Marquette%2C%20Michigan">Marquette</a> on the following March 20.
During his six-year tenure, Magner provided attention to the mission parishes of the diocese, established the diocesan newspaper, promoted U.S. Laymen's Retreat Association, and created seven catechetical schools. He died after a long illness in Marquette, at age 60. He is buried in the crypt of St. Peter Cathedral.
